paragraphs.title: Some of the Source Code is From this Book (its a good book for Twitter Scraping/Analysis)
paragraphs.text:
%md ![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/python_social_media.jpg)
- Marco has good topic coverage related to API integration from Twitter and Google ecosystem. - Chapters 1-4 are worth reading, the back end is not - Some other sites that have good API coverage are Pintrest and google + - Also covers web scraping (beautiful soup and selector gadget)

msg.data:
• Marco has good topic coverage related to API integration from Twitter and Google ecosystem.
  • Chapters 1-4 are worth reading, the back end is not
  • Some other sites that have good API coverage are Pintrest and google +
  • Also covers web scraping (beautiful soup and selector gadget)

paragraphs.title: Hook Local Package Files to Path
Verify that the twitter API keys were successfully imported on Docker-Compose Start
Lets Start by studying the worlds biggest internet troll...
Lets do Some Basic Twitter Stuff:  First Get  User Profile
paragraphs.text:
%python
from twitter_client import get_twitter_client
import json
client = get_twitter_client()
profile = client.get_user(screen_name="realDonaldTrump")
print(json.dumps(profile._json, indent =4))

paragraphs.title: Ok, maybe too big of a troll... Lets get a lesser troll so we can pull followers and friends in less than a fortnight
Here is the user profile.
paragraphs.text:
%python
from twitter_client import get_twitter_client
import json
client = get_twitter_client()
profile = client.get_user(screen_name="skibo43")
print(json.dumps(profile._json, indent =4))

paragraphs.title: Ok, lets go find some trolls...  Lets get the followers and friends of this stellar individual
Is this troll powerful?  not really
What did that code do?
Ok, lets pivot here and compare the influence of the troll vs my page
Look at my followers & friends
We need to get user timelines to compare influence
Compute Basic Network Influence... the troll wins... what does this say about me???
All the influence did was find the nearest neighbors in a directed graph...

paragraphs.title: Lets look at the followers and get ready to do some clustering in Higher Dimensions on the personal statement of his followers
K-means clustering by TF-IDF (this is a naughty troll with mean friends...)
So, How did that work???
paragraphs.text:
%md
![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/tfidf.jpg)

- #### The workhorse is the TfidfVectorizer (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer.html)

![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/kmall.png) 

- #### Simple K-Means to form groupings of like feature vectors http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.cluster.KMeans.html

msg.data:
• The workhorse is the TfidfVectorizer (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer.html)

  • Simple K-Means to form groupings of like feature vectors http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.cluster.KMeans.html

msg.data:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_hashtag_frequency.py", line 13, in <module>
    with open(fname, 'r') as f:
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'stream__Irma.jsonl'

# Chap02-03/twitter_conversation.py
import sys
import json
from operator import itemgetter
import networkx as nx

def usage():
    print("Usage:")
    print("python {} <filename>".format(sys.argv[0]))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        usage()
        sys.exit(1)
    fname = sys.argv[1]
    with open(fname) as f:
        graph = nx.DiGraph()
        for line in f:
            tweet = json.loads(line)
            if 'id' in tweet:
                graph.add_node(tweet['id'],
                               tweet=tweet['text'],
                               author=tweet['user']['screen_name'],
                               created_at=tweet['created_at'])
                if tweet['in_reply_to_status_id']:
                    reply_to = tweet['in_reply_to_status_id']
                    if tweet['in_reply_to_status_id'] in graph \
                    and tweet['user']['screen_name'] != graph.node[reply_to]['author']:
                        graph.add_edge(tweet['in_reply_to_status_id'], tweet['id'])
        print(nx.info(graph))

        sorted_replied = sorted(graph.degree_iter(), key=itemgetter(1), reverse=True)
        most_replied_id, replies = sorted_replied[0]
        print("Most replied tweet ({} replies):".format(replies))
        print(graph.node[most_replied_id])

        print("Longest discussion:")
        longest_path = nx.dag_longest_path(graph)
        for tweet_id in longest_path:
            node = graph.node[tweet_id]
            print("{} (by {} at {})".format(node['tweet'],
                                            node['author'],
                                            node['created_at']))

paragraphs.title: lets check the geostream... hum.. nothing
It is using "coordinates" where "place" would be better
https://twittercommunity.com/t/twitter-search-api-always-return-geo-null
Lets fix that up and use place instead
Ok, here we run the stream with the fix in place
That looks much better it will be the corner of the box but so what...

paragraphs.text:
%python import folium map_width=1800 map_height=600 map_sf = folium.Map([35, -90], zoom_start=4, tiles='cartodbpositron') import pickle import re # read python dict back from the file pkl_file = open('/notebook/stream__crookedhillary.pkl', 'rb') geoItems = pickle.load(pkl_file) pkl_file.close() for k in geoItems['features']: folium.Marker(location = [k['geometry']['coordinates'][1],k['geometry']['coordinates'][0]],popup = re.sub(r'\W+', ' ', k['properties']['text'])).add_to(map_sf) print "%angular " + "
" + map_sf._repr_html_() + "
"
